findings.title: Step 2 of the handover protocol can be forged
findings.description: In step 2 of the handover protocol, the participant 𝔹 needs to signal agreement that participant 𝔸 performed step 1 correctly and that 𝔹 has correctly recovered the ephemeral key 𝑡. However, the hash calculation does not include the commitment 𝑁, which means that anyone can generate a random 𝑧 and compute 𝑁 = 𝑔 𝐵.

findings.title: Hash function is used as KDF in handover protocol
findings.description: In step 1 of the key handover protocol, participant 𝔸 performs a DH key exchange with participant 𝔹 ’s public key and applies a cryptographic hash function to the resulting shared secret. The resulting value is used as a keystream to encrypt the ephemeral key 𝑡 as if using a stream cipher.

findings.title: Ceremony participants can send many delayed messages
findings.description: The ceremony runner allows participants to send ceremony data that arrives at the runner one round early, which would cause the runner to discard the previously stored data.

findings.title: Binding value can be zero
findings.description: The `gen_rho_i` function does not check that the return value is nonzero.

findings.title: The Chainflip back end and smart contracts have vulnerable dependencies
findings.description: Several dependencies with known vulnerabilities were found in the back-end and smart contract dependencies.

findings.title: Potential panic in KeyId::from_bytes
findings.description: The `KeyId::from_bytes` method panics if the input is shorter than the value of the `size_of_epoch_index` variable, opening the node to denial-of-service attacks from malicious users.

findings.title: Solidity compiler optimizations can be problematic
findings.description: Optimization bugs have occurred in the past and may occur in the future, potentially causing security vulnerabilities.

findings.title: ERC-20 token transfer fails for certain tokens
findings.description: Due to an incorrect check, nonstandard ERC-20 tokens that do not return a Boolean value when transferred could be stuck in the protocol.

findings.title: addGasNative is missing check for nonzero value
findings.description: The `addGasNative` function does not check for nonzero `msg.value` amounts.

findings.title: StakeManager contains unnecessary receive function
findings.description: The StakeManager contract contains a receive function, despite not requiring ether interactions.

findings.title: Missing events for important operations
findings.description: Inconsistent use of events to signal processing step completion or failure.

findings.title: Nonstandard ERC-20 tokens get stuck when depositing
findings.description: Due to an incorrect check, nonstandard ERC-20 tokens that do not return a Boolean value when transferred could be stuck in the protocol.

findings.title: Transfer can fail due to a fixed gas stipend
findings.description: The function govWithdrawNative has a fixed gas stipend of 2300, which may cause transfer to fail if the recipient is a proxy contract.

findings.title: Low number of block confirmations configured for external blockchains
findings.description: The chosen number of block confirmations is not adequate and can lead to exploits where a user's stake value is recorded on the State Chain but no stake is locked on Ethereum.

findings.title: Hard to diagnose error from default behavior during signer nomination
findings.description: Error occurs due to default behavior during signer nomination making it hard to diagnose.

findings.title: Failed broadcast nominees are not punished if epoch ends during broadcast
findings.description: Nominated validators who want to delay certain broadcast transactions near the end of an epoch can do so without punishment.

findings.title: Nominated broadcast signer does not always report failures in engine
findings.description: The Chainflip engine does not report transaction broadcast failures to the State Chain, which forces validators to wait for a timeout before attempting to rebroadcast the corresponding transaction.

findings.title: Threshold signature liveness protection does not account for previously punished validators
findings.description: The implementation of threshold signature liveness protection does not consider previously punished validators, which can lead to a situation where two-thirds of the authority set are suspended and the protocol cannot progress.
